discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct.Other hosts in 192.168.1.0/24 also need to be marked with critical IP precedence. Route-map CCNP permit 20 is not required, as the unmatched traffic will do the normal RIB lookup.

Selected Answer: D
No need to add a route-map with sequence 20 as the "permit any any" will capture the rest of the traffic that needs to be marked critical.

Actually , either is a typo , or every answer is wrong. How can a number standard access-list has "permit any any"? . This is invalid. 
So if is a typo and the access list number is 100 ( extended) the other command is wrong . "access-list 1 deny host 192.168.1.1" it should have been " access-list 100 deny ip host 192.168.1.1 any" . So in the END every answer is wrong . If we smoke something before the exams we should put the D :D

Correct one is C

comments.content:
parse the language carefully:An engineer configures router A to mark all inside to outside traffic from network 192.168.1.0. except from host 192.168.1.1. with critical IP precedence

All inside traffic except 192.168.1.1 needs ip precedence critical

A: Achieves this, but has a redundant route-map 20
B:No route is marked with precedence critical
C: this is a deny statement in route-map 10: route-map 20 permits the rest without marking

D: route-map 10 sets ip precedence to critical for all traffic but 192.168.1.1
Although 192.168.1.1 is not forwarded using policy based routing, it may be forwarded with the standard routing table

A achieves same thing as D but has an extra not needed route-map 20
C has an incorrect deny in the first route-map entry, so is also wrong.

this is policy based routing. This means the 192.168.1.1 is not policy routed, but normal routed. It is not ddropped. The answer is D. Answer C denies everything in sequence 10, so nothing is tagged with a precedence. Sequence 20 permits everything unmarked with dscp. So C is wrong. Same with answer B. Everything is denied in seq 10 so nothing is marked with DSCP, yet sequence 20 allows all routes to be policy routed. Since we need to mark something, B is wrong. In answer A --> First 192.168.1.1 is denied. All other routes are marked with dscp critical. Since it is denied (and not matched at all in sequence 10), it is actually matched in sequence 20. So 192.168.1.1 is marked with dscp. So answer A is wrong.

Correction,
I agree with B or D being "almost correct" but they are both still WRONG.
D will DROP traffic for 192.168.1.1 as the “route-map” has an implicit deny at the end. This is not what the question intended, it required “route-map CCNP permit 20” to be added to be OK.
B is almost OK, but lacks a “access-list 1 permit any any” at the end of the ACL.
Again, as far as i can see, there are no 100% OK answer. I Think B is best, but still it will not work as the acl is incomplete.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer configures router A to mark all inside to outside traffic from network 192.168.1.0. except from host 192.168.1.1. with critical IP precedence. The policy did not work as expected. Which configuration resolves the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
provided seems correct

After the LDP TCP connection session is established, the LSRs negotiate the session parameters, including the method of label distribution to be used. Two methods are available:

Downstream Unsolicited: An LSR advertises label mappings to peers without being asked to.

Downstream on Demand: An LSR advertises label mappings to a peer only when the peer asks for them.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/mp_ldp/configuration/xe-16-11/mp-ldp-xe-16-11-book/mp-ldp.html

Selected Answer: CD
C & D are correct

Selected Answer: CD
C & D are correct

The "no ip dhcp snooping information option command" disables the insertion of DHCP Option 82. This might be necessary in certain environments where devices (like older DHCP servers or clients) do not support or need Option 82 information.

choices.D: It improves P router performance by not performing multiple label lookup.
choices.B: It uses implicit-NULL for traffic congestion from source to destination forwarding.
choices.C: PE removes the outer label before sending to the P router.
choices.A: Downstream node signals to remove the label.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A seems OK, Penultimate Hop Popping will mean that the P before the PE pops the label as the P knows the PE can directly route it. The answer A will just indicate that the PE signals the P to do this.

comments.content: agree. The downstream (egress) PE signals to pop it with implicit-null

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
PHP improves P router performance by eliminating the need for multiple label lookups. Here’s the reasoning:

P routers are responsible for forwarding packets based on labels, but they don’t need to look up multiple labels when PHP is in place.
By removing the outermost label before the packet reaches the last hop, the penultimate hop reduces the work that needs to be done by the last hop (the egress PE router), which only has to forward the packet to its final destination.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

P router: is the second-to-last router in the MPLS path, removes the outer MPLS label before forwarding the packet to the last hop router (PE router).

PE router: is the last hop router, which receives the packet with the outer label already removed and can directly forward the packet to its final destination without needing to process any MPLS labels.


C is incorrect, P is the one which removes the outer label not PE.


nice post to read:

https://web.archive.org/web/20131213202855/http://journey4ccie.com/2013/02/04/mpls-vpns-and-issues-related-with-php-penultimate-hop-popping/
A is correct
